headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: Superyachts and the Super Rich. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: All right. We are all jealous of Alisyn Camerota right now.An all-new episode of "THE WHOLE STORY WITH ANDERSON COOPER" airs next right here on CNN. Thanks very much for joining me this evening. I'm Jim Acosta. I'll see you back here next weekend. Have a good night.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.Tonight, we take you into a world that few people get to see up close. The world of superyachts. Private boats, some of them longer than a football field. They can cost hundreds of millions of dollars and it seems there's plenty of buyers. Since the pandemic, more people than ever are building and buying them. Business is reportedly booming. They've become status symbols for the superrich and striking symbols of the economic inequality. Their impact on the environment and the oceans is a topic of debate. The U.S. has seized some superyachts of Russia's elite and now your tax dollars are surprisingly being spent to keep their ships in tip- top shape. CNN's Alisyn Camerota takes us inside this hidden world of superyachts and her first stop at the Monaco Yacht Show. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): This is Monaco. Land of the ultra-wealthy. And dotting the harbor like crown jewels are some of the world's largest superyachts. Bonjour. (Voice-over): That's no surprise considering this is the richest country in the world per capita. People here don't pay income tax, which as you can imagine, attracts millionaires and billionaires from all over the globe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A picture queen who will become a princess greets her new subjects.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA

From the TV show, "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous," that glamourized wealth and decadence decades ago, to today's popular reality show, Bravo's "Below Deck," to social feeds of celebrities lounging on yachts like Beyonce's photos on Instagram. We seem to have an almost primal fascination with rich people and how they spend their money.

utterances.speaker: WOLF BLITZER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The Obamas aboard David Geffen's yacht vacationing with Bruce Springsteen, Tom Hanks, Oprah Winfrey.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA

BERNARD D'ALESSANDRI, SECRETARY-GENERAL, MONACO YACHT CLUB: The size of the boats increase every year.

Tell me about the distinctions between superyacht, megayacht and gigayacht.

Later, we'll give you a glimpse inside the queen of the Monaco Yacht Show, one of the largest gigayachts in the world at 318 feet. Just for reference, an NFL football field from one goal line to the other is only 300 feet. So how many passengers can you take on a huge, floating football field? Generally only 12.

utterances.sentences: Not to get too technical, but in the wake of the 1912 Titanic disaster, stricter safety rules were put in place for commercial passenger ships, including having lifeboats or rafts for 125 percent of the passengers and crew, but those maritime rules are much looser for private pleasure crafts with 12 passengers or less and that's the category for most yachts.

utterances.speaker: OSNOS
utterances.sentences: But there's no limit on the number of crew. So as a result, you might have a yacht that has 12 guests and up to 50 people who are working on the boat, attending to them.
